content: The "Medicare Commission Act of 1996" is established. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program is established with 15 members appointed by the President and Senate leaders. Members can be from the executive branch, Senate, or private citizens, with a limit on political party representation. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program consists of 15 members appointed by the President and Senate leaders. Members can be from the executive branch, Senate, or private citizens, with restrictions on political party representation for appointments made by the Majority Leader and Speaker of the House. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program is composed of 15 members appointed by the President, Senate leaders, and the Speaker of the House. Appointments must adhere to political party restrictions. Members serve for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled promptly, and meetings are held as needed. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program consists of 15 members appointed by various political leaders. The Commission must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed and will meet at the Chairman's call. A majority of members form a quorum, and the Commission selects a Chairman from its members. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program consists of 15 members appointed by various political leaders. The Commission must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed and will meet at the Chairman's call. A majority of members form a quorum, and the Commission selects a Chairman from its members. SEC. 3. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission is tasked with reviewing analyses of Medicare trust funds, identifying solvency threats, analyzing potential solutions, and providing recommendations to ensure financial integrity and health benefits under the Medicare Program. The Commission is responsible for reviewing Medicare trust funds, identifying solvency threats, analyzing solutions, and providing recommendations to maintain financial integrity and health benefits. The term "Medicare trust funds" refers to the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund. The Commission must submit its report to the President and Congress within 12 months of its first meeting. The Commission established under the Social Security Act is tasked with reviewing Medicare trust funds, identifying solvency threats, and providing recommendations to maintain financial integrity and health benefits. The report must be submitted to the President and Congress within 12 months of the Commission's first meeting. Congressional leaders will consider legislation based on the Commission's recommendations within 3 months. The Commission established under the Social Security Act reviews Medicare trust funds, identifies solvency threats, and provides recommendations. Congressional leaders draft legislation within 3 months based on the Commission's recommendations to ensure long-term solvency of the Medicare trust funds. Legislation introduced in the House of Representatives must be voted on within 3 months, or the committee it was referred to will be discharged, and a motion to proceed with the legislation will be highly considered. Legislation introduced in the Senate must be voted on within 3 months, or the committee it was referred to will be discharged. Legislation introduced in the Senate must be voted on within 3 months, or the committee it was referred to will be discharged, and a motion to proceed to the consideration of the legislation will be privileged. If no vote on the legislation is taken within 3 months, a vote on endorsing commission recommendations will be required. Legislation introduced in the Senate must be voted on within 3 months. If no vote is taken, a motion to consider a joint resolution endorsing commission recommendations will be privileged. The Commission established by the Act has the power to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and use postal services. Additionally, the Act addresses personnel matters related to the Commission. The Commission established by the Act has the power to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and use postal services. In terms of compensation, members who are federal government officers or employees serve without additional pay, while those who are private citizens do not receive compensation but are allowed travel expenses. The Commission members receive compensation for their work, including travel expenses at authorized rates. The Chairman can appoint necessary personnel without following civil service laws. The Chairman of the Commission can appoint an executive director and additional personnel without following civil service laws. The Secretary of Health and Human Services can provide administrative and support services upon request. Compensation for personnel can be determined by the Chairman without following specific provisions of the United States Code. The Chairman of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and personnel, set their compensation without following certain provisions of the United States Code, detail government employees without reimbursement, and procure temporary services as needed. The Chairman of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and personnel, set their compensation without following certain provisions of the United States Code, detail government employees without reimbursement, and procure temporary services as needed. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, and temporary and intermittent services can be procured at specified rates. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting its report. Expenses will be covered by funds available to the Secretary of Health and Human Services.
